image.altText: A road sign blocking entry following heavy rain.

items.synopsis: With more wet and windy weather forecast across SA this weekend, the SES has taken the step of urging residents to avoid public areas where there is a possibility of falling branches and trees.

title.children: Risk of falling trees prompts SES warning to families amid another 'burst' of SA wet weather

image.altText: A hospital building with car park out the front

items.synopsis: Women due to give birth at the Whyalla Hospital will have to deliver at other locations as a critical workforce shortage forces the closure of the hospital's birthing services from Monday.

title.children: Critical shortage of midwives forces closure of Whyalla Hospital birthing services

image.altText: The back of an army truck with soldiers is pictured, in front of it stands Wagner chief Prigozhin.

items.synopsis: The founder of Russia's Wagner mercenary force, Yevgeny Prigozhin, says his men have crossed the border from Ukraine into Russia and are ready to go "all the way" against the Russian military.

title.children: Kremlin accuses Wagner boss of mutiny over claim Russian military attacked mercenaries

image.altText: A photo of a white submersible under water.

items.synopsis: Days of frantic waiting has ended in tragedy for the families of the Titan sub passengers. But the search for answers is just beginning, and the question now is whether lessons will be learned from the underwater implosion.

title.children: The Titan sub mystery unfolded in unimaginable horror. For those on board, it was over in a moment

image.altText: Jim gestures as he speaks at a podium.

items.synopsis: As our federal politicians prepare for their five-week winter break, two significant developments which point to much of what will shape the country — and political debate — in coming months haven't really been quite noticed, writes Laura Tingle.

title.children: We now face the grim expectation we can't avoid a recession — and that's changed the political reality

image.altText: Deputy Premier of Victoria Jacinta Allan speaks to media during a press conference.

items.synopsis: Among those sanctioned were 12 members of South Australia's Australia Day council.

title.children: Russia sanctions 48 Australians in latest sweep punishing 'Russophobic' groups

image.altText: A composite image of a man with dark hair wearing a t shirt and man with lighter grey hair in a city

items.synopsis: OceanGate co-founder Guillermo Sohnlein defends the company's deceased CEO against claims he dismissed safety warnings, as officials work to decide who will investigate the disaster.

title.children: 'Keenly aware of the risks': OceanGate co-founder defends dead CEO's approach to safety as probe launched

image.altText: OceanGate Titan submersible floating at the surface of the ocean

items.synopsis: Here's what an implosion means, how it happens and whether the passengers on the Titan submersible could have felt it.

title.children: 'They wouldn't have realised they were dying': What we know about the Titanic sub implosion

image.altText: Aerial view of rows of new houses in outer suburbia.

items.synopsis: Right now, evidence suggests a chronic lack of supply and increased demand for housing are supporting property prices and could lead to a further lift in the market, writes David Taylor.

title.children: Tens of thousands of 'missing' homes could push Australia's property prices even higher

image.altText: Silhouetted figure of a woman to the left, farm gate to the right. Sunset in the centre

items.synopsis: The ABC can reveal there is a court battle to keep a man who abducted and raped a German backpacker 10 years ago behind bars, with forensic psychiatrists fearing he was a high risk of reoffending.

title.children: A German backpacker responded to an ad to nanny in remote Queensland. It was a sex offender's trap

image.altText: The nose of an airliner is reconstructed from damaged pieces.

items.synopsis: The Australian government hits three of the men behind the downing of flight MH17 with sanctions and travel bans in a move likely to further inflame tensions with Russia.

title.children: Australia imposes travel bans and sanctions against three men over MH17

image.altText: Nurses and doctor pictured during medical procedure, generic image.

items.synopsis: The controversial tool has been implemented in Auckland, taking a person's ethnicity into account when placing them on non-urgent surgery waitlists.

title.children: Ethnicity criteria to rank patients for surgery in New Zealand labelled 'a courageous move'

image.altText: A relaxed koala with a fitness tracker around a front leg sits in a gum tree

items.synopsis: Researchers from Flinders University in Adelaide use Fitbit heart rate monitors on koalas and infrared cameras and acoustic equipment in the burrows of little penguins to gauge the impact of human interference.

title.children: Why these heart-rate monitors are helping scientists understand how drones affect koalas

image.altText: A silhouette of sharks under a surfer.

items.synopsis: From magnets to smelly wax, electric fields to orca calls, the shark-deterrent market is booming. Here's how the different devices stack up to research.

title.children: Personal shark deterrents are flooding the market, but research shows some may work better than others

image.altText: eX de Medici

items.synopsis: In the face of Australia's political conservatism, punk tattoo and visual artist eX de Medici chose a perhaps unlikely weapon: watercolour.

title.children: Howard’s election made this tattooist so mad, she embraced a 'tool of destruction'

image.altText: A coach bus with a trailer on dirt by the side of a road.

items.synopsis: A bus driver has been charged after a coach full of children from a Victorian school ran off the road north of Adelaide and became bogged in a paddock.

title.children: Bus full of children from Victorian school runs off road into paddock in regional SA

image.altText: Martin Duku walking outside a court building wearing a suit and glasses

items.synopsis: The Adelaide Magistrates Court is preparing to sentence Martin Duku, who was working as a police officer based in Port Augusta when he indecently assaulted two women.

title.children: Prison not a 'safe place' for South Australian police officer guilty of sexually assaulting two women, court hears

image.altText: The bow of the RMS Titanic.

items.synopsis: From the sustained pop culture boost brought on by James Cameron's 1997 blockbuster to the psychology of voyeurism, there are many reasons humanity remains fascinated with the iconic 1912 shipwreck.

title.children: Why is the Titanic's wreckage such a drawcard for explorers?

image.altText: Close-up of platypus

items.synopsis: A Wildlife Preservation Society of Queensland survey after last year's floods found Sandy Creek, which skirts the edges of western Brisbane and Ipswich, is home to a significant platypus population.

title.children: Between three motorways and in a heavily industrialised area, one of Australia's most elusive creatures can be found

image.altText: Creekbed and road overflowing with water outside a house

items.synopsis: A rainband stretching more than 3,000 kilometres will engulf Australia next week, delivering soaking rains from the Pilbara and Kimberley, across the outback to the eastern seaboard.

title.children: Week-long drenching forecast across Australia as El Niño takes a rain check

image.altText: Josie Hess has bright red hair and smiles in front of a colourful background

items.synopsis: An international panel of experts has outlined six rules for making healthy, ethical porn. But they're nothing new to regional Victorian porn producer Josie Hess, who wants the edicts to become the norm.

title.children: Is there such a thing as healthy, ethical porn? This filmmaker thinks so — as long as you follow certain rules

image.altText: Police vehicle and tape block off a crime scene in Yanco, NSW

items.synopsis: A woman in her 50s will front court today for predatory driving in a fatal crash that killed a 36-year-old woman and three boys near Leeton in April.

title.children: Driver to front court for 'predatory driving' in fatal Yanco crash that killed three children

image.altText: A man surfing a huge wave.

items.synopsis: The massive wave is earning a reputation around the world as it draws daredevil surfers and photographers to the region.

title.children: Surfers take on 'mountain' of a wave fuelled by huge swell off WA's south coast

image.altText: Two women standing and not looking at each other with view of skyline, mountains and clouds in the background.

items.synopsis: Australian politics is facing a sexual harassment reckoning. Thanks to a crucial scene in a Netflix political drama, so is Taiwan. How did the show Wave Makers become a rallying cry for Taiwan's MeToo movement, and why has it taken so long for people to come forward with allegations of sexual harassment?

title.children: What does 'eating tofu' have to do with Taiwan's rising #MeToo movement?

image.altText: Rows and rows of cylinders in cages sit on tarmac. In the background are excavators, trees and water tanks

items.synopsis: This toxic waste dump in Victoria contained everything from PFAS to asbestos — and even cash and a dog wrapped in a mattress — buried in 32 locations, some the size of AFL fields. Now $40 million later, the clean-up is almost complete.

title.children: Inside the massive clean-up of this giant, secret and highly toxic dump — and how it changed recycling for good

image.altText: Indiana Jones prepares to swap a gold idol for a bag of sand in a scene from Raiders Of The Lost Ark.

items.synopsis: The fifth Indiana Jones film is here, but is it the end for the whip-cracking archaeologist?

title.children: Is The Dial of Destiny really the end for Indiana Jones?

image.altText: Two hand hold out a pile of black fertiliser pellets.

items.synopsis: Spreading human waste onto crops may not sound appealing, but a multi-million-dollar Icon Water scheme is hoping to turn Canberra's sewage into a valuable farming product.

title.children: Turning poo into produce: Canberra's plan to make fertiliser from human waste

image.altText: A man in cricket whites is surrounded by teammates congratulating him.

items.synopsis: He is half the age of the man he has been brought into the England squad to back up and once caught the eye of Shane Warne — so who is Rehan Ahmed?

title.children: England leg spinner on the brink of 146-year history if he gets second Test call up

image.altText: Woman with hair pulled back, wearing funky black glasses and a green jumper smiles slightly at camera

items.synopsis: Lily Foster battled addiction for 20 years and "lost" everything. She wants to share her "lived experience" so others can benefit but in Tasmania, it's not easy for her to make her voice heard.

title.children: 'I lost everything to addiction': Lily wants to share what she's learned to help others

image.altText: Annabel Sutherland smiles while holding her bat and helmet aloft

items.synopsis: England powers to a strong score on day two of the women's Ashes, as Australia lets a crucial wicket slip after choosing not to review.

title.children: DRS strikes again as England reclaims ground on Australia after Sutherland's ton
